question: $P \land Q$ if P is false and Q is true
information: The logical AND ($\land$) operation returns true only if both$P$and$Q$are true. In this case,$P$is false and$Q$is true, so$P \land Q$is false.

question: $P \oplus Q$ if P is true and Q is true
information: The logical XOR ($\oplus$) operation returns true if exactly one of$P$or$Q$is true, but not both. Here, both$P$and$Q$are true, so$P \oplus Q$is false.

question: $P \iff Q$ if P is true and Q is false
information: The logical biconditional ($\iff$) returns true only if$P$and$Q$are both true or both false. In this case,$P$is true and$Q$is false, so$P \iff Q$is false.

question: $\lnot (P \land Q)$ if P is true and Q is false
information: $P \land Q$would be false because$Q$is false. The negation ($\lnot$) of false is true, so$\lnot (P \land Q)$is true.

question: $\lnot P \lor Q$ if P is true and Q is true
information: $\lnot P$would be false since$P$is true. However,$Q$is true, and the logical OR ($\lor$) operation only needs one true value to return true. So,$\lnot P \lor Q$is true.

question: $P \rightarrow \lnot Q$ if P is false and Q is true
information: The logical implication ($\rightarrow$) returns false only if$P$is true and$Q$is false. In this case,$P$is false, which makes the implication true regardless of the value of$Q$. Therefore,$P \rightarrow \lnot Q$is true.

question: $P \lor Q$ if $P$ is false and $Q$ is false
information: The logical OR ($\lor$) returns true if either $P$ or $Q$ is true. In this case, both $P$ and $Q$ are false, making $P \lor Q$ false.

question: $P \lor Q$ if $P$ is false and $Q$ is false
information: The logical OR ($\lor$) returns true if either $P$ or $Q$ is true. In this case, both $P$ and $Q$ are false, making $P \lor Q$ false.
